column5: too

column5: we gotta know if this study was big enough to even be legit

column2: the more we can trust if this fish oil move is really a game-changer. The less it holds up
column3: the more we gotta say
column4: ""Hold up
column5: maybe we shouldn't all jump on this just yet."" Either way
column6: the evidence is key to knowin";"The following report appeared in the newsletter of the West Meria Public Health Council.

column5: we recommend the daily use of Ichthaid — a nutritional supplement derived from fish oil — as a good way to prevent colds and lower absenteeism.""

column1: Dear West Meria Public Health Council
Your argument is quite intriguing and appealing. However

column5: in preventing illnesses such as colds. Secondly

column8: the efficacy and potential side effects of Ichthaid should be thoroughly researched before recommending it widely as a solution to reduce absenteeism.

column1: I read with great interest your recent article on corporate downsizing in Elthyria. My attention was particularly drawn to the contention that the main portion of skilled employees who have lost jobs due to downsizing encounter severe economic difficulties for extended periods before securing alternative employments. Nonetheless
column2: this assertion is contradicted by a fresh report on the Elthyrian economy
column3: which disclosed that there have been a greater number of employments generated than terminated since 1999. This has resulted in the unemployment rate declining to its most reduced level in decades. In addition
column4: two-thirds of these freshly established jobs have been in sectors that normally provide wages above the average
column5: and the huge majority of these employments are full-time.

column2: certain precise proof is needed. First
column3: a comprehensive breakdown of the types of employment generated since 1999 is necessary to determine if they are comparable in quality to the ones lost due to downsizing. Additionally
column4: an examination of the demographic profile of the employees in these new industries is crucial to ascertain if all groups have equally benefited from the employment surge. Lastly
column5: a long-term analysis of the sustainability of these new jobs ought to be conducted to determine if they offer reliable sources of income in the foreseeable future.

column2: an in-depth analysis of the evidence outlined above could possibly challenge the argument presented in your article and provide a clearer perspective on the impact of the recent economic changes in Elthyria.

column3: a business major may benefit from taking courses in the arts or sciences
column4: which can help them develop critical thinking skills and provide a deeper understanding of the world.

column2: requiring students to take courses outside their major can help them discover new interests and potential career paths. For example

column1: The success of Groveton's honor code is likely due to its emphasis on student accountability. column2: and this shift in accountability has been proven to reduce cheating.

column1: 288;288;108;"Educational institutions should actively encourage their students to choose fields of study in which jobs are plentiful.
Write a response in which you discuss the extent to which you agree or disagree with the claim. In developing and supporting your position
column2: be sure to address the most compelling reasons and/or examples that could be used to challenge your position.";analyze_an_issue;https://web.archive.org/web/20220324020435/https://www.ets.org/gre/revised_general/prepare/analytical_writing/issue/pool;"Input: So check it out
column3: we got this recommendation comin' from the head of staff folks up to the big boss at Acme Publishing Company.

column2: a whole bunch of other outfits been sayin' when they folks took the Easy Read Speed-Reading Course
column3: they work game got way up. There was dis one cat who finished a thick 500-page report in just a cup of coffee; and another one went from being a helper boss to the big cheese in the office in less than 365. It's clear as day
column4: the quicker you flip through them pages
column5: the more you can take in during your hustle. And peep this
column6: Easy Read only gonna hit Acme's wallet for 500 bucks a head—that ain't nothing compared to the come-up. That dough also get you a three-week get-together in Spruce City
column7: plus you locked in for life with the Easy Read news. No doubt
column8: if Acme makes all the team take this Easy Read thing
column9: we gonna be sitting pretty.""

column2: let's break down this pitch and peep the game behind it. We gotta scope out what's being thrown at us outright and the low-key stuff they ain't spelling out. This whole argument is propped up on the idea that reading fast means doing better work
column3: period. But hold up
column4: we gotta ask: does speeding through pages really mean folks is understanding and using what they read? Plus
column5: they saying one person's come-up means everybody gonna climb the same way—that's a big if right there.

column2: that $500 per person might sound like small change
column3: but we gotta wonder if that cash could be flipped better elsewhere. And they talking 'bout benefits
column4: but what if them benefits don't show up like they promise? Is that course really gonna teach folks in a way that sticks with them
column5: and what's the real cost if it don't?

column1: This whole talk is leaning heavy on the belief that faster is always better and that dropping a few bills is gonna pay off big time without fail. If them under-the-rug assumptions don't hold up
column2: then the whole argument might just topple. We gotta make sure we ain't buying a dream before we throw down that green.";"The following is a recommendation from the personal director to the president of Acme Publishing Comapny.

column1: Many other compagnies have recently stated that having their employees take the Easy Read Speed-Reading Course has greatly improved productivity. One graduate of the course was able to read a 500-page report in only to hours; anothe graduate rose from an assistant manager to vice-president of the company in under a year. Obviusly
column2: the faster you can read
column3: the more information you can absorb in a single work day. Morever
column4: Easy Read would cost Acme only $500 per employee — a small price to pay when you consider the benefits. Included in this fee is a three-week seminar in Spruce City and a lifelong subscription to the Easy Read newsletter. Clearly
column5: Acme would benefit greatly by requiring all of our employees to take the Easy Read course.""

column1: Write a response in which you examin the stated and/or unstated assumtions of the argument. Be sure to explain how the argument depends on these assumtions and what the implications are for the argument if the assumtions prove unwarranted.";I agree that educational institutions should actively encourage their students to choose fields of study in which jobs are plentiful. It is important for students to be aware of the job market when making their educational and career choices. If students are aware of the job prospects in their chosen field
column2: they can make an informed decision about their future. Additionally
column3: educational institutions should provide resources and information about the job market to their students. This can include providing data about the job market
column4: hosting guest speakers from relevant industries
column5: and offering internships or job shadowing opportunities. By actively encouraging students to choose fields of study with plentiful job prospects
column6: educational institutions can help students make informed decisions and be successful in their future careers.;"This pitch is trying to sell Acme Publishing Company on a speed-reading course called Easy Read. The speaker is emphasizing that the course is a good investment because it can help Acme employees increase their work output and increase their status in the office. They are also emphasizing that the cost of the course is low compared to the potential benefits.

column1: The speaker is not mentioning any potential drawbacks to the course
column2: such as the possibility that it may not actually increase reading speed or comprehension or that it may not result in any long-term benefits for Acme employees. They are also not mentioning any potential alternatives to the course that could provide similar benefits but cost less.
this pitch is making a lot of promises about the potential benefits of the Easy Read course
column3: but it is not providing enough evidence to support those claims. Acme should consider other options before investing in this course.";"The argument for requiring Acme employees to take the Easy Read Speed-Reading Course depends on several assumptions. First
column4: it assumes that the course can actually increase productivity. This assumption is based on anecdotal evidence
column5: and more research is needed to determine whether or not this is true. Second
column6: it assumes that the cost of $500 per employee is a reasonable investment. This is a financial assumption that should be evaluated in light of the potential benefits of the course. Finally
column7: it assumes that a three-week seminar in Spruce City and a subscription to the Easy Read newsletter are necessary components of the course. Again
column8: this is an economic assumption that should be examined in order to determine the value of the course.

column1: If any of these assumptions prove unwarranted
column2: then the argument for requiring Acme employees to take the Easy Read Speed-Reading Course will weaken. For example
column3: if the course is found to be ineffective at increasing productivity
column4: then the argument will be weakened. Similarly
column5: if the cost of the course is found to be excessive
column6: or if the seminar or newsletter are found to be unnecessary
column7: then the argument will be weakened. Ultimately
column8: the argument depends on these assumptions being valid
column9: and thus should be examined for their validity.";{'flesch_reading_ease': 41.9

column1: It is time for the city of Grandview to stop funding the Grandview Symphony Orchestra. It is true that the symphony struggled financially for many years

column4: we recommend that the city eliminate funding for the Grandview Symphony Orchestra from next year's budget. We predicts that the symphony will flourish in the years to come even without funding from the city.""

column2: miles away from where these Dodecan cats usually kick it. It's about piecing together the whole story
column3: you dig?";Archaeologists have long thought that an artifact called the pemchint were used by Dodecan people solely as a music instrument. Pemchints consists of hollow pieces of bone
column4: shell
column5: or woods that are tied together with longer straps. When whirling in the air

column8: they was always excavated in proximity with others musicals artifacts. Recently
column9: a pemchint were found alongside Dodecan hunters' tools located miles from the nearest known Dodecan settlings
column10: while no other musical-related objects were found in the areas. Clearly
column12: the pemchint were used by Dodecan hunters
column13: who most probably used the sounds to repels dangerous wildlife.;I agree to some extent with the statement. Major cities are often the epicenter of social change and the primary sites of cultural production. They are the places where new ideas are formed
column16: and they provide the laboratory for experimentation that shapes the broader culture. At the same time

column2: a company that manufactures saxaphones.

column1: On this year's survey about work habits
column2: our employees tended to strongly agree with the idea that if they took less time to complete their assigned work
column3: the quality of their work would suffer. However
column4: we recently conducted an internal study that disproves this idea wrong. Managers acros several divisions identified an overtime group: the employees who worked an average of 48 or more hours per week over the past year instead of the expected 40 hours per week. We then looked at the number of documented work errors produced by all of our employees during the past year and found that the overtime group was responsible for significantly more work errors overall than their fellow employees. On the basis of this findings
column5: our recommendation to the company president is to require employees at Dexter Gorman Instruments to complete their work during the regular 40-hour work week and allow overtime only for urgent circumstances.""

column6: those whose executives reported needing no more than 6 hours of sleep per night had higher profit margins and faster growth. These results suggest that if a business wants to prosper
column7: it should hire only people who need no more than 6 hours of sleep per night.""

column1: When examining the argument presented in the article
column2: it is crucial to identify the assumptions made by the author and evaluate their validity. Firstly
column3: the assumption that the success of advertising firms is solely dependent on the sleep duration of their executives is too simplistic. Success in business is a multi-faceted concept that involves various factors beyond just sleep patterns. Secondly
column4: the argument relies on the assumption that causation can be inferred from the correlation observed between executives' sleep duration and profitability. However
column5: correlation does not necessarily imply causation
column6: and there may exist other variables influencing the results. Lastly
column7: the argument suggests a blanket statement that businesses should hire individuals who require less than 6 hours of sleep per night to prosper. This assumption overlooks the individual differences in sleep needs and productivity levels
column8: which can vary greatly among people. If these assumptions are proven unwarranted
column9: the implications for the argument would be significant. It would undermine the validity of the conclusion drawn and highlight the need for a more comprehensive analysis of the factors contributing to business success.";"I agree that governments should focus on solving the immediate problems of today rather than on trying to solve the anticipated problems of the future. column10: and trying to solve anticipated problems may lead to wasted resources and effort. For example

column12: it may be better off using those resources to address the needs of its citizens today. Additionally
column13: if a government focuses on solving immediate problems
column14: it can build trust with its citizens by showing that it is addressing their needs in a timely manner.

column5: if a government is able to address an immediate problem in a unique and innovative way
column6: it may set a precedent for other governments to follow.

column2: Dr. Field

column1: 503;503;323;"The following appeared as a memorandum from the Human Resources director at Dexter Gorman Instruments
column2: a company that manufactures saxophones.

column1: On this year's survey about work habits
column2: our employees tended to strongly agree with the idea that if they took less time to complete their assigned work
column3: the quality of their work would suffer. However
column4: we recently conducted an internal study that proves this idea wrong. Managers across several divisions identified an overtime group: the employees who worked an average of 48 or more hours per week over the past year instead of the expected 40 hours per week. We then looked at the number of documented work errors produced by all of our employees during the past year and found that the overtime group was responsible for significantly more work errors overall than their fellow employees. On the basis of these findings
column5: our recommendation to the company president is to require employees at Dexter Gorman Instruments to complete their work during the regular 40-hour work week and allow overtime only for urgent circumstances.""

column1: 514;514;334;"The following appeared in an article written by Dr. Karp
column2: an anthropologist.
Dr. Field
column3: a noted anthropologist
column4: visited the island of Tertia and concluded from his observations that children in Tertia were reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. However
column5: my recent interviews with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia show that these children spend much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. This research of mine proves that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture is invalid and thus that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is invalid as well. The interview-centered method that my team of graduate students is currently using in Tertia will establish a much more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions there and in other island cultures.""
